protocol_name: HERP: Haploid Engineering and Replacement Protocol for Saccharomyces
protocol_name_html: HERP: Haploid Engineering and Replacement Protocol for Saccharomyces
description:
This protocol is from:
Alexander WG, Doering DT,and Hittinger CT (2014) High-Efficiency Genome Editing and Allele Replacement in Prototrophic and Wild Strains of Saccharomyces. Genetics 198:859-866; doi:10.1534/genetics.114.170118

Please see the full manuscript for additional details.

The purpose of this document is to provide you with an easy‐to‐follow guide to using the HERP cassettes. We will go through the preparation of the selection and counterselection media, the culturing and transformation for insertion of the HERP cassettes, and counterseletive replacement of the HERP cassettes.
authors: William G. Alexander, Drew T. Doering, and Chris Todd Hittinger
guidelines:
C. Inserting the HERP cassettes

1) Design primers with overhangs that target the cassette to your desired locus.    

a) The 5' overhangs dictate where the cassette will be integrated, and the length needed depends on the
species you're manipulating (40 bp for S. cerevisiae, S. paradoxus, S. uvarum, & S. eubayanus, 50 bp for S. mikatae,
and 70 for S. kudriavzevii; S. arboricola's length requirement is unknown). The longer these overhangs are the more
efficient integration will be, although longer overhangs usually mean longer oligonucleotides, which are expensive
and sometimes difficult to use.

b) The 3' ends amplify the cassette from either the primer or yeast genomic DNA. While we have
constructed both plasmids and stably‐integrated yeast strains with all three HERP cassettes, the yeast strains provide
an advantage over the plasmid constructs. HERP cassettes with an adjacent I‐SceI recognition site are unstable in
bacteria, resulting in the plasmid never being recovered. In yeast, SCE1 is actively repressed while growing on glucose,
which prevents leaky nuclease expression. Because of this active repression, the yeast strains tolerate an I‐SceI site
adjacent to the HERP cassettes, which in turn reduces the length of oligonucleotide needed to provide both a priming
site and a targeting overhang. The authors strongly recommend using the yeast strains as PCR templates for HERP
cassette amplification. If the plasmids are used, then the 18‐bp I‐SceI sequence must be included on the oligo
between the 3' amplification sequence and the 5' targeting overhang (Table S3).

components.data: Add the following components to a 2‐L Erlenmeyer flask:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add the following components to a 2‐L Erlenmeyer flask:

components.data: Preparing Media: Yeast Extract‐Peptone‐Glycerol +Antifolates (YPGly+ AF)
components.name: Section

source_data.description:
This recipe is from:
Alexander WG , Doering DT , and  Hittinger CT (2014) High-Efficiency Genome Editing and Allele Replacement in Prototrophic and Wild Strains of Saccharomyces. Genetics 198:859-866; doi:10.1534/genetics.114.170118

See the full protocol for step-by-step YPGly+ AF preparation instructions.
source_data.authors: William G. Alexander, Drew T. Doering, and Chris Todd Hittinger
source_data.guidelines:
This recipe is from:
Alexander WG , Doering DT , and  Hittinger CT (2014) High-Efficiency Genome Editing and Allele Replacement in Prototrophic and Wild Strains of Saccharomyces. Genetics 198:859-866; doi:10.1534/genetics.114.170118

See the full protocol for step-by-step YPGly+ AF preparation instructions.
------------------------
1) Add the following components to a 2‐L Erlenmeyer flask:
‐10 g yeast extract
‐20 g peptone
‐5 g sulfanilamide
‐50 mg hypoxanthine
‐18 g agar
‐900 mL ddH2O

Mix to dissolve as much as possible (agar and sulfanilamide won't dissolve until heated).

2) Autoclave for no more than 20 minutes on a liquid cycle.

3) Once autoclaved, cool to 50° in a water bath, then add the following and mix:
‐5 g thymidine
‐200 mg methotrexate
‐100 mL 50% (v/v) glycerol, sterilized
(NOTA BENE: the standard operating procedure for adding compounds after autoclaving is to dissolve them in a
solvent, filter, then add to the media; this generally is difficult or impossible for methotrexate and thymidine due to
the amount required. For the last two years, I've been adding the solid chemicals directly to the cooled media, and
I've never had contamination. I suspect that the extreme conditions prevent microbial growth. Also, both
methotrexate and thymidine are sensitive to heat, so take care to not add them early.)

4) Pour ~20 mL into plastic petri dishes and allow to set. You have now made YPGly +AF media

source_data.annotation: NB: an alternate method to make SC +FUdR plates is to make a 1000x stock solution of 50 mg/mL FUdR in water, filter, then spread enough concentrate onto the surface of a premade SC plate to bring the final concentration to 50 μg/mL (20 μL of concentrate mixed with 80 μL of water, then spread onto the surface of a plate containing 20 mL of SC agar)

components.data: Design primers with overhangs that target the cassette to your desired locus. (See the guidelines for details.)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Design primers with overhangs that target the cassette to your desired locus. (See the guidelines for details.)

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Amplify the HERP cassette of choice using your targeting primers and a high‐fidelity polymerase such as New England Biolab's Phusion system. If your reaction makes use of DMSO or other harsh chemicals, clean your PCR product with a column before proceeding.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Amplify the HERP cassette of choice using your targeting primers and a high‐fidelity polymerase such as New England Biolab's Phusion system. If your reaction makes use of DMSO or other harsh chemicals, clean your PCR product with a column before proceeding.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Culture your strain of choice by inoculating 50 mL of YPD media with enough overnight culture of your strain to bring the OD600 to 0.2‐0.25. Shake at the optimal temperature for your strain or species until the culture's OD600 reaches 0.85‐1.0.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Culture your strain of choice by inoculating 50 mL of YPD media with enough overnight culture of your strain to bring the OD600 to 0.2‐0.25. Shake at the optimal temperature for your strain or species until the culture's OD600 reaches 0.85‐1.0.

components.name: Section

components.data: Harvest the cells by centrifugation in a 50‐mL conical vial at 3000 RPM for 5 minutes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Harvest the cells by centrifugation in a 50‐mL conical vial at 3000 RPM for 5 minutes.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Remove supernatant, wash with 25 mL water, and spin at 3000 RPM for 5 minutes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove supernatant, wash with 25 mL water, and spin at 3000 RPM for 5 minutes.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Remove supernatant and suspend cells in 1 mL of water.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove supernatant and suspend cells in 1 mL of water.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Aliquot 100 μL cell suspension to microcentrifuge tubes, spin for 30 seconds at max speed in a microcentrifuge, and remove supernatant.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Aliquot 100 μL cell suspension to microcentrifuge tubes, spin for 30 seconds at max speed in a microcentrifuge, and remove supernatant.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 20 of HERP: Haploid Engineering and Replacement Protocol for Saccharomyces
source_data.protocol_name: HERP: Haploid Engineering and Replacement Protocol for Saccharomyces
source_data.protocol_name_html: HERP: Haploid Engineering and Replacement Protocol for Saccharomyces
source_data.annotation: NB: for optimal transformation efficiency, you must empirically determine what time, temperature, and/or additive conditions give the most transformants for your species or strain. Our suggestion is to use a yeast replicating plasmid with a dominant drug marker and evaluate a number of conditions as in Gietz & Woods, 2002. In general, 30 minute heat shocks at 42° works well for S. cerevisiae, while the psychrophillic species generally only tolerate heat shocks of 37° (S. kudriavzevii only tolerate 34°. S. mikatae doesn't tolerate the transformation reaction conditions well, and requires a room temperature incubation of 10 minutes followed by a 37° shock for 5 minutes.
source_data.thread_text: NB: for optimal transformation efficiency, you must empirically determine what time, temperature, and/or additive conditions give the most transformants for your species or strain. Our suggestion is to use a yeast replicating plasmid with a dominant drug marker and evaluate a number of conditions as in Gietz & Woods, 2002. In general, 30 minute heat shocks at 42° works well for S. cerevisiae, while the psychrophillic species generally only tolerate heat shocks of 37° (S. kudriavzevii only tolerate 34°. S. mikatae doesn't tolerate the transformation reaction conditions well, and requires a room temperature incubation of 10 minutes followed by a 37° shock for 5 minutes.
source_data.body: NB: for optimal transformation efficiency, you must empirically determine what time, temperature, and/or additive conditions give the most transformants for your species or strain. Our suggestion is to use a yeast replicating plasmid with a dominant drug marker and evaluate a number of conditions as in Gietz & Woods, 2002. In general, 30 minute heat shocks at 42° works well for S. cerevisiae, while the psychrophillic species generally only tolerate heat shocks of 37° (S. kudriavzevii only tolerate 34°. S. mikatae doesn't tolerate the transformation reaction conditions well, and requires a room temperature incubation of 10 minutes followed by a 37° shock for 5 minutes.

components.data: Once heat‐shocking has been completed, spin the reactions for 30 seconds at max speed, remove the supernatant, and suspend the cells in 600 μL of YPD.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once heat‐shocking has been completed, spin the reactions for 30 seconds at max speed, remove the supernatant, and suspend the cells in 600 μL of YPD.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Transfer to glass culture tubes and spin in a culture wheel for 3 hours at the strain's or species' optimal temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer to glass culture tubes and spin in a culture wheel for 3 hours at the strain's or species' optimal temperature.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Spread 200 μL of recovered cells to each of three YPGly +AF plates. Only one 200 μL volume of control reaction, however, needs to be plated. Once all the liquid has been absorbed, store agar up at the optimal temperature. Colonies will appear in 3‐10 days.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Spread 200 μL of recovered cells to each of three YPGly +AF plates. Only one 200 μL volume of control reaction, however, needs to be plated. Once all the liquid has been absorbed, store agar up at the optimal temperature. Colonies will appear in 3‐10 days.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Streak colonies out to fresh YPGly +AF plates. Analyze by amplifying target locus via PCR and/or sequencing across the insertion junction.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Streak colonies out to fresh YPGly +AF plates. Analyze by amplifying target locus via PCR and/or sequencing across the insertion junction.

components.data: Inserting the HERP cassettes
components.name: Section

components.data: Once you have molecularly confirmed the insertion of the HERP cassette, phenotypically confirm its sensitivity to FUdR by spotting ~1,000 cells onto SC +FUdR plates multiple times. Sensitive strains should exhibit no growth, while insensitive strains will rapidly grow.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once you have molecularly confirmed the insertion of the HERP cassette, phenotypically confirm its sensitivity to FUdR by spotting ~1,000 cells onto SC +FUdR plates multiple times. Sensitive strains should exhibit no growth, while insensitive strains will rapidly grow.

components.data: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette

components.data: Once your HERP insertion is confirmed and you have established FUdR sensitivity, begin by inoculating the strain in 50 mL of 2X YPA100 +4% galactose (see main text) to an OD600 of 0.2‐0.25 and culture at the optimal temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once your HERP insertion is confirmed and you have established FUdR sensitivity, begin by inoculating the strain in 50 mL of 2X YPA100 +4% galactose (see main text) to an OD600 of 0.2‐0.25 and culture at the optimal temperature.

components.data: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette

components.data: Once an OD600 of 0.85‐1.0 is reached, repeat steps C4 to C6, except replace the HERP cassette PCR product in C6 with your desired replacement PCR product.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once an OD600 of 0.85‐1.0 is reached, repeat steps C4 to C6, except replace the HERP cassette PCR product in C6 with your desired replacement PCR product.

components.data: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette
components.name: Section

components.data: Once the heat shock is completed, remove the supernatant and suspend in 600 μL water.

source_data.description: Once the heat shock is completed, remove the supernatant and suspend in 600 μL water.

components.name: Section

components.data: Spread 200 μL onto each of three SC plates.
components.name: Description

components.data: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette

components.data: Incubate at optimal temperature for 24 hours.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate at optimal temperature for 24 hours.

components.data: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette

components.data: After 24 hours, incubate plates at 4° for one hour.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After 24 hours, incubate plates at 4° for one hour.

components.data: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette

components.data: Lightly replicate plates to SC +FUdR plates.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Lightly replicate plates to SC +FUdR plates.

components.data: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Counterselective Replacement of the HERP Cassette

components.data: Re‐replicate to fresh FUdR plates no more than once a day to reduce background growth. Colonies will appear in 2‐5 days, longer if glucose is replaced by glycerol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Re‐replicate to fresh FUdR plates no more than once a day to reduce background growth. Colonies will appear in 2‐5 days, longer if glucose is replaced by glycerol.
